comments.comment_text:
1:20 - Prime, im sorry but aren't you tired of just literally hating web frontend devs? 
First of all, what are these absurd expectation of a junior dev? 
Even with a React todo app there would be plenty of stuff to talk about:
- i made the app feel more responsive by caching data locally
- i've implemented partial restoration algo for cases where local data shape doesnt match the data from server due to a new update
- i've implemented realt-time sync between tabs
- oh i made a bunch of nice animations - when you drag a bottom drawer, the main app container in the background moves cause it looks nice and feels native
- oh ive implemented some keyboard navigations for advanced users
- when deleting a todo, instead of moving focus to the body, i move it to the next todo

there's a lot of stuff you can think about when making UIs - even if its a simple todo app
even if you think all the stuff i've listed sounds easy: 
1) if we're talking about displaying passions - it does show passions of somebody who thinks of how the UI they're making is gonna be used. Recently at my job I've updated the pagination components so that pressing number key while pagination buttons are in focus, it will move focus to the pagination input and immediately put in the number you've pressed. was it hard to do? no, it was like 15 lines of code at best. yet I wasn't the first person to work on this component who thought it something that should have been done.
2) if all of that is easy (a clerk integration as you say) - then what's the conclusion? web dev is easy? so what should you do if you wanna be a frontend web dev? make a video game? great advice.

as for Prime's understanding of frontend - I know you did React at Netflix and you even made some optimizations to react internals. Yet when Ryan Florence gave a you a challenge to implement his Remix newsletter with HTMx - what you've presented to him was a a form with 1 input which woulf after submission either display 1 error or redirect you to to a success page. And then Ryan listed a bunch of things you didnt implement. If that's supposed to be impressive, I'm not surprised you think of webdev this way.
comments.author: @huge_letters

comments.comment_text: @17:50 about on press vs on release --  I think both are correct in different scenarios. I agree exactly that when you're mouse clicking in a UI on a button, you should be able to drag off before releasing to cancel. But if you're using a key press to do an attack in a game, then it 100% should be "on press" not "on release" (I'm aware some games actually make this a user option for quick-casting where "while you hold it" it shows you an aiming indicator, and that's fine too, as long as it's optional especially) -- but in general, like jumping or sliding in a game should be something that happens on press, as it makes the game feel snappier to the user's input.

comments.comment_text:
Release vs. Press
Press feels more responsive because the action is immediate.
Release is preferential to the need for, as you pointed out, recovery from a mis-click.

If I'm playing an FPS, I would definitely want on Press/Keydown.
If I'm navigating a website I definitely want it to be on Release, because the website may dynamically change beneath my click.

~33m If you ever want to see complicated by intuition over reality. Try tutoring an intelligent teenager in maths.
They'll be doing it right, getting it easily, and it will feel too easy, so they'll think either they're wrong, or they're not done.

comments.comment_text:
While this was certainly useful as far as showing an overview of the motivation of making the game and some critical techniques behind implementing core systems of the game itself, it doesn't get to what _programmers_ would consider the "hard" part and why so many "one-man team" games often don't get past proof-of-concept or to a point of enjoyability - designing the actual gameplay experience (final/non-placeholder graphics and other assets, levels, etc).

Around 2011 or 2012 I made a tech demo for a vertical scrolling shoot-em-up (aka "vertical shmup;" think games like Raiden, Ikaruga, 19XX, or the Touhou series) using JavaScript and the Sphere Engine. I was so focused on getting the underlying systems to work that I paid no attention to making an experience that would be _fun_ or _enjoyable._ I didn't prototype any proper enemy layouts, weapon loadouts, bullet sprays to navigate (for those who like those sorts of bullet-hell games), things like that. Over time, I learned that things like that should still be present in spec and focus even if the immediate task is not necessarily directly relevant. While I consider myself artistically inclined, I simply didn't put in the effort needed to make more than one player ship, one test enemy ship, a smattering of particle graphics, and some placeholder backgrounds and text graphics.

Mark Brown at Game Maker's Toolkit has an ongoing series of videos describing the making of his indie game "Mind Over Magnet" where he goes over not just the process of making and troubleshooting the systems, but also making and troubleshooting the levels, assets, and even the processes themselves. Even if one might not agree 100% with his specific philosophy or praxis (he _is_ using a Unity-based workflow, after all), he has shown himself to be a guy who puts his money where his mouth is in his dev efforts after building his channel making videos for years analyzing what makes games tick.

comments.comment_text: If you store and update game state totally separately from render state you can do another neat thing (beyond the 'scrubbing'). You can run an entire replay of the game deterministically, which is the beginnings of implementing lockstep multiplayer and effectively testing it for desyncs. If you use deterministic physics or some kind of horrible hack to make floats cross-platform deterministic it all magically works.
